text: cAMP - dependent regulation of proenkephalin by <extra_id_0> JunD <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> JunB <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> : positive and negative effects of AP-1 proteins .

We demonstrate that <extra_id_0> JunD <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , a component of the AP-1 transcription factor complex , activates transcription of the human proenkephalin gene in a fashion that is completely dependent upon the cAMP - dependent protein kinase , protein kinase A . Activation of proenkephalin transcription by <extra_id_0> JunD <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is dependent upon a previously characterized cAMP - , phorbol ester - , and Ca ( 2+ ) - inducible enhancer , and <extra_id_0> JunD <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is shown to bind the enhancer as a homodimer .

Another component of the AP-1 transcription complex , <extra_id_0> JunB <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , is shown to inhibit activation mediated by <extra_id_0> JunD <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

As a homodimer <extra_id_0> JunB <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is unable to bind the enhancer ; however in the presence of <extra_id_0> c-Fos <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , high - affinity binding is observed .

text: Furthermore , <extra_id_0> JunD <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is shown to activate transcription of genes linked to both cAMP and phorbol ester response elements in a protein kinase A - dependent fashion , further blurring the distinction between these response elements .

These results demonstrate that the transcriptional activity of an AP-1 - related protein is regulated by the cAMP - dependent second-messenger pathway and suggest that <extra_id_0> JunD <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and other AP-1 - related proteins may play an important role in the regulation of gene expression by cAMP - dependent intracellular signaling pathways .
